Traveler

The Moscow Times.com 
 
 Tuesday, October 19, 2004. Page 1.
 
  Putin Calls a Bush Loss a Victory for Terrorists 
 
 by Simon Saradzhyan
 Staff Writer
 
 President Vladamir Putin on Monday made his strongest endorsement yet for his friend U.S. President George W. Bush, saying "international terrorism" will claim victory over the international antiterrorism coalition if Bush loses.
 
 "I believe that the activities of terrorists in Iraq are not as much aimed at the coalition as at President Bush personally, " Putin said. "The goal of international terrorism is to prevent the election of President Bush to a second term."
 
 http://www.themoscowtimes.com/stories/2004/10/19/002.html
 
 
 While Vladamir Putin was still somewhat critical of Bush concerning Iraq, and though he said that he would like to work with either candidate, whomever wins in this election, this endorsement of Bush in the War on Terrorism is one that should be heeded by voters given Putin's past criticism of Bush.

Sorry to nit-pick but:
 
 
The country's (Poland) economy is in the toilet and sinking. 

 
 Are you sure about this?, I mean their economic growth is rather good at the moment, far surpassing most european countries as well as the US and their high unemployment has decreased the last year.

 
 All I know is what my friend tells me after he comes back from Poland. He sees all his friends getting poorer and poorer, no jobs, no pay for jobs that do exist, whole families living in 2 bedroom apartments with more moving in, etc etc. I guess it's that same kind of economic indicators that say an economy is doing well just because some corporations are turning a profit despite how many people are scraping by to live.
 
 This page says something, not sure of the total picture it paints:
 http://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/www/en/laenderinfos/laender/laender_ausgabe_html?type_id=12&land_id=136
 
Besides budgetary reform, Poland`s biggest economic policy problem is unemployment, which has remained at 18% for the last two years. As of 2004, farmers working less than 1 hectare automatically count as unemployed. As a result of this statistical effect, unemployment currently amounts to about 20%.

 That's what my friend sees. He doesn't see any of this:
 
Polish foreign trade has recorded robust growth in recent years, on the import and the export side. The focus has shifted increasingly to the EU countries (70% of exports and 61% of imports) with Germany playing a key role for Poland. Polish exports have been developing particularly well for some time, with export revenue in 2003 rising by 23%, for example

 
 So reconstruction contracts may have nothing to do with national unempoyment rates, but surely it has to do with:
 
The outlook in public finances are not as rosy: The budget deficit in 2003 made up 5% of GDP, as it had already done in 2002. National debt is slowly nearing the constitutional ceiling of 60% of GDP. In response, the government is now seeking to halt the rise in public expenditure through far-reaching budget reforms (Hausner Plan)
.

 I don`t live in Poland (even though I have somer elatives residing there), so I don`t have any direct experience. But my general impression is that the economy is picking up speed at large. Wether this will be experienced by every aspect of the polish society is not very likely, but it is still far from going down the toilet. At the moment, the largest problem seems to be the omnious unemployment figures, but these have been really bad for years (if not worse). The advantages of joining the European Union is starting to show soon, and it wouldn`t surprise me if Polands economy is going to make rather huge strides forward in the not-so-distant future.
